py-tidymodels
  • py-yardstick: Model Metrics
  • View page source

py-yardstick: Model Metrics

The py_yardstick package provides 17 comprehensive model evaluation metrics for regression and classification.

Main Functions

Metric Set

py_yardstick.metric_set(*metrics)[source]

Create a metric set that computes multiple metrics at once.

Parameters:

*metrics (Callable) Metric functions to include

Return type:

Callable

Returns:

Function that computes all metrics and returns combined DataFrame

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([1.1, 2.2, 2.9, 4.1, 4.8])
>>> my_metrics = metric_set(rmse, mae, r_squared)
>>> my_metrics(truth, estimate)
      metric     value
0       rmse  0.141421
1        mae  0.160000
2  r_squared  0.989796

Regression Metrics (7)

py_yardstick.rmse(truth, estimate, **kwargs)[source]

Root mean squared error.

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) Actual values

  • estimate (Series) Predicted values

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([1.1, 2.2, 2.9, 4.1, 4.8])
>>> rmse(truth, estimate)
   metric     value
0    rmse  0.141421
py_yardstick.mae(truth, estimate, **kwargs)[source]

Mean absolute error.

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) Actual values

  • estimate (Series) Predicted values

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([1.1, 2.2, 2.9, 4.1, 4.8])
>>> mae(truth, estimate)
  metric  value
0    mae    0.16
py_yardstick.mape(truth, estimate, **kwargs)[source]

Mean absolute percentage error.

Note: MAPE is undefined when truth contains zeros. These values are excluded.

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) Actual values (should not contain zeros)

  • estimate (Series) Predicted values

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value (percentage, 0-100)

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([10, 20, 30, 40, 50])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([11, 22, 29, 41, 48])
>>> mape(truth, estimate)
  metric  value
0   mape    5.5
py_yardstick.smape(truth, estimate, **kwargs)[source]

Symmetric mean absolute percentage error.

SMAPE is bounded between 0 and 200, and handles zeros better than MAPE.

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) Actual values

  • estimate (Series) Predicted values

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value (percentage, 0-200)

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([10, 20, 30, 40, 50])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([11, 22, 29, 41, 48])
>>> smape(truth, estimate)
  metric     value
0  smape  5.384615
py_yardstick.r_squared(truth, estimate, **kwargs)[source]

Coefficient of determination (R).

Standard R using total sum of squares.

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) Actual values

  • estimate (Series) Predicted values

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([1.1, 2.2, 2.9, 4.1, 4.8])
>>> r_squared(truth, estimate)
      metric     value
0  r_squared  0.989796

Classification Metrics (10)

py_yardstick.accuracy(truth, estimate, **kwargs)[source]

Classification accuracy.

Proportion of correctly classified observations.

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) True class labels

  • estimate (Series) Predicted class labels

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([0, 1, 0, 1, 1])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([0, 1, 0, 0, 1])
>>> accuracy(truth, estimate)
    metric  value
0  accuracy    0.8
py_yardstick.precision(truth, estimate, positive_class=1, **kwargs)[source]

Precision (positive predictive value).

Proportion of positive predictions that are correct.

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) True class labels

  • estimate (Series) Predicted class labels

  • positive_class Label for positive class (default: 1)

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([0, 1, 0, 1, 1])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([0, 1, 1, 0, 1])
>>> precision(truth, estimate)
     metric     value
0  precision  0.666667
py_yardstick.recall(truth, estimate, positive_class=1, **kwargs)[source]

Recall (sensitivity, true positive rate).

Proportion of actual positives that are correctly predicted.

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) True class labels

  • estimate (Series) Predicted class labels

  • positive_class Label for positive class (default: 1)

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([0, 1, 0, 1, 1])
>>> estimate = pd.Series([0, 1, 1, 0, 1])
>>> recall(truth, estimate)
  metric     value
0  recall  0.666667
py_yardstick.roc_auc(truth, estimate_prob, positive_class=1, **kwargs)[source]

Area under the ROC curve.

Requires predicted probabilities (not class labels).

Parameters:

  • truth (Series) True class labels

  • estimate_prob (Series) Predicted probabilities for positive class

  • positive_class Label for positive class (default: 1)

  • **kwargs Additional arguments (for consistency with metric_set)

Returns:

metric, value

Return type:

DataFrame with columns

Examples

>>> truth = pd.Series([0, 1, 0, 1, 1])
>>> estimate_prob = pd.Series([0.1, 0.8, 0.3, 0.7, 0.9])
>>> roc_auc(truth, estimate_prob)
  metric  value
0  roc_auc    1.0

Examples

Individual Metrics

from py_yardstick import rmse, mae, r_squared

# Calculate metrics (returns DataFrames)
rmse_df = rmse(y_true, y_pred)
mae_df = mae(y_true, y_pred)
r2_df = r_squared(y_true, y_pred)

# Extract scalar values
rmse_val = rmse(y_true, y_pred).iloc[0]["value"]
mae_val = mae(y_true, y_pred).iloc[0]["value"]
r2_val = r_squared(y_true, y_pred).iloc[0]["value"]

Metric Set

from py_yardstick import metric_set, rmse, mae, r_squared

# Create metric set
metrics = metric_set(rmse, mae, r_squared)

# Evaluate
results = metrics(y_true, y_pred)
print(results)
#    .metric     value
# 0     rmse  5.234567
# 1      mae  4.123456
# 2  r_squared  0.856789

With DataFrames

from py_yardstick import metric_set, rmse, mae
import pandas as pd

# DataFrame with predictions
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'truth': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
    'estimate': [1.1, 2.2, 2.9, 4.1, 4.8]
})

# Evaluate directly on DataFrame
metrics = metric_set(rmse, mae)
results = metrics(df['truth'], df['estimate'])

Classification Metrics

from py_yardstick import metric_set, accuracy, precision, recall, f1_score
import numpy as np

# Binary classification
y_true = np.array([0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 1, 0, 1])
y_pred = np.array([0, 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 1])

# Evaluate classification metrics
metrics = metric_set(accuracy, precision, recall, f1_score)
results = metrics(y_true, y_pred)
print(results)
#       .metric     value
# 0    accuracy  0.875000
# 1   precision  1.000000
# 2      recall  0.800000
# 3    f1_score  0.888889
